Użyj {@area map of the Sword Coast|00e|x}, aby zaznaczyć postępy bohaterów w lesie. Za każdym razem, gdy bohaterowie wchodzą na nowy heks na mapie, każ nawigatorowi wykonać test Mądrości ({@skill Survival}) DC 10. Jeśli test się powiedzie, drużyna pozostaje na kursie. Jeśli się nie powiedzie, wrócą na kurs, po tym jak stracą {@dice 1d4} mil na poruszanie się w złym kierunku.

entries.name: A Boar-ing Encounter
entries: Wkrótce po wejściu do lasu bohaterowie mają spotkanie, które nie jest tym, czym się wydaje. Przeczytaj na głos poniższy tekst w ramce:
Około sześćdziesięciu stóp przed Tobą, na małej polanie stoi dzik. Dzik spogląda na Ciebie podejrzliwie.

Dzik jest w rzeczywistości samicą {@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP} w postaci dzika. Kotowata, Drethna, atakuje tylko w obronie własnej. Jeśli bohaterowie okrążą dzika lub w inny sposób unikną konfrontacji, mogą kontynuować swoją podróż. Jeśli dzik zostanie oszczędzony, rzuca się do ucieczki, aby ostrzec kotowiaków w {@adventure Woodland Manse|DIP|14}, że do lasu wkroczyli obcy.

entries.name: Arrival
entries: Jeśli bohaterowie podążają wzdłuż rzeki od {@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6}, przybywają od wschodu. Jeśli idą prosto z {@area Phandalin|02c|x}, zbliżają się od południa. Kiedy dotrą na miejsce, przeczytaj na głos poniższy tekst w ramce:

Obóz drwali rozciąga się wzdłuż południowego brzegu rzeki, gdzie na piaszczystej plaży ustawiono kilkanaście namiotów. W pobliżu doku stoi domek z balami ułożonymi w stosy pod markizą. Starsze domki w pobliżu zostały zburzone, pozostały po nich tylko kamienne kominy i fundamenty. Wokół obozu panuje ponura cisza, nikogo nie widać.

{@creature Ankheg||ankhegs} ukrywają się pod ziemią i polegają na swoich {@sense tremorsense} w celu wykrycia ofiary. Wybuchają z ziemi w kwadratach oznaczonych na mapie jako "erupcja ankheg", gdy spełnione są pewne warunki, opisane w {@area areas L3|152|x} i {@area L6|155}. Jeśli prowadzisz ten scenariusz dla jednej postaci, w danym momencie można napotkać tylko jednego ankhega.

entries.name: Camp Locations
entries: Poniższe miejsca są oznaczone kluczem do mapy obozu drwali.

entries.name: L1. Cabins on the Rocks
entries: Domki te zostały w większości zburzone, ale ich ruiny stoją na szczycie wysokiej na 10 stóp skarpy skalnej, przez którą ankhegowie nie mogą się przebić.

entries.name: L2. Old Cabin and Chimney
entries: Z tej chaty pozostał jedynie zrujnowany kominek, którego komin w większości się zawalił, oraz kamienne fundamenty, przez które ankhegowie nie mogą się przebić.

entries.name: Totem
entries: Postać, która przeszuka komin, znajdzie zakopany w jego gruzach totem: trzynaście malutkich, androgynicznych figurek patyków zanurzonych w świńskiej krwi, zapisanych malutkimi symbolami błyskawic i związanych włosami w wiązkę. Postać, która zda test na inteligencję DC 15 ({@skill Religion}), może odkryć, że celem totemu jest sprowadzenie nieszczęścia na wszystkich, którzy przebywają w jego pobliżu. Zniszczenie totemu sprawia, że wszystkie ankhegi, które jeszcze nie zaatakowały, tracą zainteresowanie obozem i odchodzą w głąb.

entries.name: L3. Office and Tool Storage
entries: Domek ma drewnianą podłogę i jest podzielony na dwa pomieszczenia. Większe pomieszczenie jest zagracone sprzętem do wyrębu lasu (piły, skórzane uprzęże do wspinania się na drzewa itp.) Pod podłogą ukryty jest {@creature ankheg}. Kiedy postać po raz pierwszy przekroczy próg pomieszczenia, ankheg przebija się przez deski podłogowe w kwadracie oznaczonym "erupcja ankheg" i atakuje.

Tibor Wester, człowiek {@creature commoner}, zabarykadował się w mniejszym biurze na północy. Przycisnął swoje biurko do drzwi i skulił się na nim. Stojąc przed jakąkolwiek decyzją, Tibor dokonuje najbardziej tchórzliwego, egoistycznego wyboru.

entries.name: L4. River Dock
entries: Można tu zacumować łodzie wiosłowe i barki rzeczne, choć w momencie przybycia bohaterów nie ma żadnej z nich.

entries.name: L5. North Camp
entries: Martwe ognisko otoczone jest sześcioma namiotami, w każdym z nich znajduje się pościel i apteczka. Dalsze oględziny wykazały, że namioty i śpiwory zostały częściowo rozpuszczone przez jakiś kwas w sprayu. Ślady stóp i dziwne znaki na piasku sugerują, że zaatakowano tu i wywleczono kilku humanoidów. Postać, która zda test na Inteligencję DC 10 ({@skill Investigation}), może wywnioskować, że humanoidy zostały zabite i wciągnięte do piasku przez potwory grzebiące w ziemi. Ankhegowie zawalają za sobą swoje tunele, nie pozostawiając możliwości podążania za nimi.

entries.name: L6. South Camp
entries: Ten obóz jest podobny do obszaru L5, ale pod nim ukryte są trzy {@creature Ankheg||ankhegs}. Kiedy stworzenie znajdzie się w odległości 20 stóp od kwadratu oznaczonego na mapie jako "erupcja ankheg", z ziemi w tym kwadracie wyskakuje wrogi ankheg i walczy, dopóki nie zostanie zabity.

data.name: Mountain's Toe Gold Mine
entries: Kopalnia złota "Mountain's Toe" jest przeznaczona dla postaci na 4 poziomie, ale postacie na 3 poziomie mogą przetrwać, jeśli unikają niepotrzebnej walki lub posiadają magiczną broń. Postacie na poziomie 5. lub wyższym będą mniej narażone na niebezpieczeństwo, ale powinny skorzystać z możliwości odgrywania ról.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Kopalnia złota w Mountain's Toe, należąca do konsorcjum biznesowego w Neverwinter, ma ostatnio problemy z wydajnością. Właściciele zatrudnili bezwzględnego nadzorcę o imieniu {@creature Don-Jon Raskin|DIP}, aby uporządkował sytuację. Ale ani Raskin, ani właściciele nie wiedzą, że kopalnię z problemami przejęła niedawno banda wilkołaków, która nazywa się Gangiem Wąsatych.

entries.name: Quest Goals
entries: Aby zakończyć {@area Mountain's Toe Quest|03b|x}, poszukiwacze przygód muszą bezpiecznie eskortować {@creature Don-Jon Raskin|DIP} do kopalni. Kiedy zobaczy, że {@creature Wererat||wererats} ją zaatakowały, Raskin nakłania bohaterów, aby wytępili "szkodniki". Jeśli bohaterowie odmówią, Raskin będzie musiał sam wynegocjować rozejm z wilkołakami - i szybko zostanie w nie zamieniony.

entries.name: Roleplaying Don-Jon Raskin
entries: Pełen przechwałek i opowieści o swoich wielkich wyczynach, {@creature Don-Jon Raskin|DIP} chodzi i mówi jak olbrzym. Pracował jako poszukiwacz złota, górnik, handlarz futrami, szeregowiec i wielorybnik. Przez kilka sezonów prowadził nawet punkt handlowy na obrzeżach Neverwinter. Jeśli bohaterowie wezmą udział w misji eskortowania Raskina do kopalni złota w Górskim Palcu, zatrzymają się u {@area Stonehill Inn|02d|x} w Phandalin. Zarządca miasta {@area Harbin Wester|037|x} zawarł umowę z pracodawcami Raskina, aby nadzorca bezpiecznie dotarł do kopalni.

Gdyby jego pracodawcy nie nalegali na zapewnienie eskorty, Raskin równie chętnie wybrałby się w podróż sam. Spodziewa się jednak, że młodzi poszukiwacze przygód chętnie opowiedzą mu o jego wyczynach, a on sam skrycie cieszy się na takie towarzystwo.

entries.name: Travel to the Mine
entries: Najszybszym sposobem dotarcia do kopalni z {@area Phandalin|02a|x} jest udanie się na północny wschód, omijając podnóża Gór Mieczowych. Kopalnia znajduje się zaledwie 15 mil od Phandalin, więc jeśli bohaterowie wyruszą o świcie, dotrą tam przed zachodem słońca.

entries.name: Mine Features
entries: Wszystkie tunele i jaskinie w kopalni są wykute w skale, przez którą przebiegają cienkie żyły rudy złota. Inne cechy wspólne opisano poniżej.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Sufity w całym budynku mają wysokość 8 stóp i są wzmocnione w regularnych odstępach drewnianymi pilastrami i belkami.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Wszystkie drzwi są wykonane z drewna, mają żelazne zawiasy i klamki. Drzwi są wyposażone w zamki, ale żadne z nich nie są zamknięte. Klucze potrzebne do ich otwierania i zamykania przepadły - zostały skradzione przez poprzedniego nadzorcę, który uciekł z kopalni.

entries.name: Light
entries: Latarnie naftowe wiszą na hakach sufitowych w każdym pomieszczeniu i tunelu.

entries.name: Dead Orcs
entries: Kiedy grupa znajdzie się w odległości pięciu mil od kopalni, przeczytaj na głos poniższy tekst w ramce:
Po prawej stronie wznosi się niski grzbiet, za którym widać Góry Mieczowe zarysowujące szare niebo. Ale bliżej coś jest rozrzucone na skalistym podłożu dziewięćdziesiąt stóp przed Tobą.
"Czy to nie jest coś" - mówi Don-Jon, wskazując na sześć martwych orków.

Orkowie zostali zabici przez białego smoka Cryovaina. Są odziani w zbroje skórzane, a ich wielkie topory i oszczepy leżą na ziemi wokół nich. Każda postać, która zbada zwłoki i zda test na Mądrość DC 12 ({@skill Medicine}), może stwierdzić, że orków zabiło trzy dni temu ekstremalne zimno. Jeśli gracze nie są w stanie ustalić, co się stało, Don-Jon mówi: "Wygląda na to, że biały smok wybawił nas z kłopotów".

entries.name: Arrival
entries: Bohaterowie docierają do zachodniego wejścia do kopalni, które możesz opisać w następujący sposób:
Tunel, ukryty wśród krzewów, wwierca się w podnóże strzelistej, ośnieżonej góry. Nad ujściem tunelu znajduje się drewniana deska z wyrytym w języku potocznym napisem "Palec Góry".
Don-Jon nie ma mapy kopalni i nigdy wcześniej jej nie odwiedzał, więc nie wie nic o jej układzie.

entries.name: Mine Locations
entries: Poniższe lokalizacje są przypisane do mapy kopalni złota Mountain's Toe.

entries.name: M1. Guard Post
entries: Jaskinia ta jest strzeżona przez dwie kobiety {@creature Wererat||wererats} w formie hybrydy. Oferują one eskortowanie nowo przybyłych do nadzorcy kopalni, Zeleen Varnaster, w obszarze M4.

entries.name: M2. Wooden Posts
entries: O ściany opierają się tu drewniane słupy służące do zabezpieczania tuneli i jaskiń.

entries.name: M3. Crates and Casks
entries: Przy ścianach tego magazynu stoi kilkanaście pustych skrzyń i podobna liczba pustych beczek.

entries.name: M4. Wererat Den
entries: W jaskini porozrzucane są kilofy, łopaty i inne narzędzia górnicze. W północno-wschodniej części znajdują się cztery {@creature Giant Rat||giant rats}. W południowo-zachodniej części znajduje się {@creature Wererat||wererats} w ludzkiej postaci: po jednym samcu wilkołaku na każdego członka drużyny (w tym {@creature Don-Jon Raskin|DIP}, ale nie na pomocników) oraz samica wilkołaka o imieniu Zeleen Varnaster - przywódczyni Gangu Whiskered. Jeśli Zeleen zginie, inny wilkołak przejmuje rolę przywódcy, dopóki któryś z nich przeżyje.

Wilkołaki najechały kopalnię po tym, jak orkowie wyparli je z ich poprzedniego legowiska - starej kapliczki w pobliżu {@area Conyberry|00f|x} (patrz "{@adventure Shrine of Savras|DIP|11}"). Wilkołaki mówią, że wrócą do swojego starego legowiska, jeśli bohaterowie pozbędą się orków z kapliczki, ale to tylko podstęp. Wilkołaki nie mają zamiaru opuścić kopalni.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Postacie, które przeszukają jaskinię, znajdą dwa worki ukryte pod gruzami. Jeden worek zawiera dziesięć kawałków rudy złota wielkości pięści, każdy o wartości 10 gp. W drugim znajdują się 82 sp, 450 cp i para {@item goggles of night}. Jeśli bohaterowie zdobędą i zidentyfikują gogle, przekaż kartę {@item Goggles of Night} graczom lub mogą się do niej odnieść w {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}.

entries.name: M5. Storeroom
entries: W środku jaskini ustawiono kilkanaście skrzyń z suchą żywnością i dziewięć beczek z wodą pitną.

entries.name: M6. Sleeping Quarters
entries: W tej grocie znajduje się kilkanaście drewnianych łóżeczek.

entries.name: M7. Gold Storage
entries: W tej jaskini znajdują się dwie taczki i pusty kosz.

entries.name: M8. Equipment Storage
entries: Przechowywane są tu kilofy, łopaty i taczki.

entries.name: M9. Dead End
entries: O tylną ścianę tunelu opiera się martwy człowiek-górnik z kilofem. Oględziny zwłok ujawniają, że górnik został zadźgany na śmierć.

entries.name: M10. Overseer's Office
entries: Wereraty splądrowały jaskinię, w której znajduje się biurko, krzesło, pusta drewniana skrzynia i łóżeczko.

entries.name: M11. Carrion Crawler
entries: W tym tunelu, którego północny koniec znajduje się 20 stóp w górę skalistego zbocza góry, znajduje się {@creature carrion crawler} legowisko. Postacie mogą pokonać zbocze po udanym teście Wytrzymałości DC 10 ({@skill Athletics}). Pełzacz nie może otworzyć drzwi na południowym końcu tunelu, więc przywiera do sufitu w środku tunelu i atakuje każdego, kto zbliży się z dowolnego kierunku.

entries.name: M12. Sleeping Quarters
entries: W tej jaskini znajduje się sześć drewnianych łóżeczek.

entries.name: M13. Rat-Infested Cave
entries: W tej jaskini znajduje się pięć {@creature Giant Rat||giant rats} osób, które atakują każdego, kto otworzy drzwi do obszaru M14.

entries.name: M14–M15. Miners' Retreat
entries: Te jaskinie są domem dla pięciu głodnych krasnoludzkich górników. Są to {@creature Commoner||commoners} mówiący w języku potocznym i krasnoludzkim, mający {@sense darkvision} zasięg do 60 stóp. Górnicy odmawiają oddania kopalni bandzie "plugawych szczurów". Szczury zakładają, że górnicy uciekną lub umrą z głodu.

entries.name: M16. Graveyard
entries: Na tym polu znajduje się pierścień ziemnych grobów z kilofami wystającymi z ziemi w miejscach, gdzie powinny znajdować się nagrobki. Pochowano tu dziesięciu górników, którzy zginęli w walce z wereratami o kontrolę nad kopalnią.

data.name: Shrine of Savras
entries: "Shrine of Savras" is balanced for characters of 1st to 6th level. This location is not connected to any quest, though one of the entries in the Phandalin Tales table might lure adventurers here. Characters might also visit the shrine after hearing of it from the wererats in the {@adventure Mountain's Toe Gold Mine|DIP|10}.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Five miles south of {@area Conyberry|00f|x} is a shrine dedicated to Savras, god of divination and fate. Many years ago, the shrine's priest-seers foresaw a barbarian attack on Conyberry, giving the townsfolk time to escape. Not all the townsfolk chose to flee, but those who did went to the shrine and brought much of the town's gold with them.

The barbarians eventually tracked the townsfolk to the shrine, besieged it, and slaughtered everyone inside. In the days leading up to this final battle, the priest-seers helped the townsfolk hide their gold in plain sight. They melted down the coins and recast them into a bell, which they painted and hung in the shrine's belfry (replacing the old iron bell). The gold bell hangs there to this day.

Over the years, many other creatures have occupied the shrine. Most recently, a gang of wererats laired here until they were driven out by orcs displaced by Cryovain the white dragon. Recently, ogres wandered by the shrine, saw the orcs, and decided to join them.

entries.name: Arrival
entries: An old dirt trail stretches from the outskirts of Conyberry to the shrine, which characters first see from a distance. Read the following boxed text aloud:

A ruin stands in the middle of a vast field north of the rocky foothills of the Sword Mountains. An old stone temple with a belfry jutting from its peaked roof is enclosed by stone walls, many sections of which have collapsed. The trail ends at a crumbling gatehouse, the doors to which were sundered long ago. Three of the four towers that once stood at the corners of the outer walls have collapsed. Only the northeast tower remains, and a guard stands atop it.

The guard spotted atop the northeast tower ({@area area S6|17e|x}) is an {@creature orc}. During the day, the characters can't approach the shrine without being seen by this sentry, as there are no places to hide in the level field surrounding the shrine. If the characters wait until nightfall, clouds obscure the moon and enable them to approach unseen, as long as they stay outside the 60-foot range of the orc's {@sense darkvision}. If the orc spots the characters, it cries out, rousing the shrine's other occupants. Once roused, all those occupants attack.

The Enemy Roster table adjusts the number of {@creature Orc||orcs} and {@creature Ogre||ogres} in the shrine based on the level of the characters and the number of characters in the party, not counting sidekicks.

entries.caption: Enemy Roster
rows: 2 orcs per character plus 1 ogre in the courtyard ({@area area S2|17a|x}), 1 orc atop the northeast tower ({@area area S6|17e|x})
3 orcs per character plus 2 ogres in the courtyard ({@area area S2|17a|x}), 1 orc atop the northeast tower ({@area area S6|17e|x})
4 orcs per character plus 3 ogres in the courtyard ({@area area S2|17a|x}), 1 orc atop the northeast tower ({@area area S6|17e|x})
4 orcs per character plus 4 ogres in the courtyard ({@area area S2|17a|x}), 1 orc atop the northeast tower ({@area area S6|17e|x})

entries: When rolling initiative for these foes, roll once for all the orcs and once for all the ogres.

entries.name: Shrine Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of the Shrine of Savras. Squares filled with rubble are {@book difficult terrain|PHB|8|Difficult Terrain} (see {@book the rulebook|PHB}).

entries.name: S1. Gatehouse
entries: The gatehouse is 20 feet high, and its outer doors have been smashed to flinders. A rusty iron portcullis blocks the south exit, but is bypassed by a rubble-filled hole in the southwest corner of the gatehouse. The winch to raise the portcullis has been destroyed, but the portcullis can be lifted manually with a successful DC 25 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check if desired.

entries.name: S2. Courtyard
entries: The orcs and ogres camp in this grassy courtyard, which is littered with bones, broken weapons, and shattered armor from past battles. The courtyard has four quadrants. The ogres claim the southeast quadrant, while the orcs claim the remaining quadrants. See the Enemy Roster table for the number of {@creature Orc||orcs} and {@creature Ogre||ogres} present.
The courtyard's northwest and northeast quadrants contain rotted wooden troughs and posts that were once used to feed, water, and tether horses.

entries.name: S3. Northwest Tower
entries: This tower is open to the sky and strewn with rubble.

entries.name: S4. Southwest Tower
entries: This roofless tower has a rubble-filled break in its southeast wall.

entries.name: S5. Southeast Tower
entries: Little remains of this tower. Lying amid the debris is a rusty iron bell that weighs 500 pounds.

entries.name: S6. Northeast Tower
entries: This tower is the only one of the shrine's four towers that has not fallen. An iron ladder inside the tower climbs to a stone trapdoor in the ceiling, through which characters can reach the tower's battlemented rooftop. An {@creature orc} watches the surrounding countryside from atop the tower.

entries.name: S7. Main Hall and Belfry
entries: Rows of crumbling pillars support the 40-foot-high vaulted ceiling of this hall. Humanoid bones litter the dusty floor, and a 10-foot-square hole in the ceiling leads to the belfry. No rope hangs from the bell, which appears to be made of untarnished copper. The belfry can be reached from outside by climbing the outer walls and rooftop, which requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Characters can reach the belfry from inside using magic such as a {@spell spider climb} or {@spell fly} spell.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Close examination of the bell reveals that it's thin sides are solid gold covered with peeling copper paint. The bell, which is 3 feet wide and weighs 50 pounds, hangs from an iron fixture bolted to a wooden crossbeam. A character with carpenter's tools or smith's tools can use them to detach the bell from the beam in 1 minute. Any creature under the bell when it falls must succeed on a DC 12 Dexterity check to get out of the way, or take 14 ({@dice 4d6}) bludgeoning damage. The gold bell is worth 2,500 gp.

entries.name: S8. Visitors' Sanctuary
entries: Guests of the shrine were housed here. Later, the wererats used this area as a lair. The room contains six beds with moldy mattresses, the shattered remains of a wooden table and six chairs, and a soot-stained fireplace containing a rusty cauldron hanging from a spit. A narrow break in the north wall provides an alternative exit.

entries.name: S9. Priest-Seers' Sanctuary
entries: The priest-seers of Savras slept and cooked their meals here. All the furnishings in this area have been destroyed, and part of the south wall has collapsed.

entries.name: S10. Altar of Fate

entries: Six stone pillars brace the vaulted ceiling of this temple, the floor of which is buried under a thick layer of dust. Also covered in dust are four humanoid skeletons in tattered priestly vestments, lying near a stone altar situated in an alcove under four narrow windows. Carved into the front of the altar is a humanoid eye.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of divination magic around the altar. If Cryovain has been slain, nothing happens when a character touches the altar. Otherwise, any character touching the altar experiences a vision lasting 1 minute, during which time the character is {@condition incapacitated}. In the vision, the character floats through the roof of the shrine, soars toward {@adventure Icespire Hold|DIP|8}, and sees the {@creature Young White Dragon||white dragon} asleep on the fortress's rooftop. (The divination power of the altar is effectively telling the characters where they must go to defeat the dragon.) A character receives this vision only once. Nothing happens to a character who touches the altar a second time.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Any character who searches the altar and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check realizes that the altar's base doesn't quite touch the floor. The altar has stone rollers built into it and can be pushed 3 feet to the south, revealing an unlocked wooden coffer tucked inside a 1-foot-square cavity in the floor. This coffer contains 57 gp and a {@item mystery key|XGE}. If the characters acquire and identify the {@item mystery key|XGE}, give the players the {@item Mystery Key|XGE} card or they can reference it in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}.

data.name: Tower of Storms
entries: "Tower of Storms" is not connected to any quest, though one of the entries in the Phandalin Tales table might lure the adventurers here. This location is balanced for characters of 3rd level, but lower-level characters can survive if they're cautious and rest often.
Before running this location, review the {@book underwater combat rules|PHB|9|Underwater Combat} in {@book the rulebook|PHB}.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: The Tower of Storms is more than just a lighthouse—it's a temple dedicated to Talos, the evil god of storms. Moesko, the half-orc {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorite} who guards the lighthouse, uses its pulsing beacon to draw ships to their doom, for the light acts as an irresistible lure to passing seafarers who sail too close to shore. The source of the beacon's eerie green light is Moesko's own heart, which was torn from his chest in a ritual. If the heart is destroyed, the beacon's light goes out.

The lighthouse is built atop a barren, 80-foot-high outcropping of rock. At low tide, a narrow causeway extends from the shore to this outcropping, allowing easy access to the lighthouse. This causeway is 5 feet above sea level at low tide. At high tide, the causeway and the sandy beach are submerged under 5 feet of water.

entries.name: Travel to the Lighthouse
entries: The Tower of Storms stands along the coast roughly 35 miles west of {@area Phandalin|02a|x}. If the characters leave Phandalin at dawn, they can reach the {@area High Road|011|x} by nightfall and spend a long rest camping nearby. As the characters travel west of the High Road the next day, they see a storm brewing out to sea. By the time they reach the 100-foot-high cliffs overlooking the lighthouse and the Sea of Swords, the thunderstorm has reached the coast.

entries.name: Arrival
entries: The characters arrive at low tide, when the causeway leading to the lighthouse is above sea level. Describe the location to the players as follows:

Below the high cliff that hugs the coastline, an outcropping of rock is nearly surrounded by water, with only a narrow causeway connecting it to the beach below. Atop this outcropping is a stone building surmounted by a lighthouse tower. An eerie green light pulses from this beacon, shining westward out to sea. With each green pulse of light, you hear the thump of a slow-beating heart.

Characters searching for a safe way down the cliffs discover a staircase carved into a narrow fissure. They can follow these steps all the way down to the shore just east of {@area area T1|18e|x}. Crawling along the beach as they arrive there is a {@creature giant crab}.

The giant crab waves its claws at the characters, who can interpret this behavior as a friendly gesture with a successful DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check. A sea elf named Miraal used magic to imbue this creature with an Intelligence of 10 and the ability to speak Common. If the characters approach it peacefully, the crab says, "Well met!" and tries to strike up a conversation, during which it imparts the following information:

items: "Evil harpies nest atop the rocky outcropping."
"There are sharks in these waters, but the one to fear is a mean old brute named Daggermaw. She'll bite your head off and take pleasure in it."
"Five shipwrecks are spread around the rock beneath the lighthouse. I'll fetch treasure from one of these wrecks if you help me."

entries.name: Helping the Giant Crab
entries: If the characters agree to help the giant crab, it asks them to lay to rest its dead sea elf master, Miraal, whose spirit haunts a nearby cave (area T1). If the characters do so, the crab thanks them and makes good on its promise, retrieving the {@item +1 weapon} from the wreck of the {@i Star-Crossed Lover} (see the {@area Shipwrecks table|19e|x}).

entries.name: Tower of Storms Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of the Tower of Storms.

entries.name: T1. Haunted Cave
entries: Rough-hewn steps climb a 7-foot-high tunnel that passes all the way through a 30-foot-tall natural pillar of rock. A damp, 8-foot-high cave encrusted with lichen is connected to this tunnel. The cave remains above sea level at high tide and is haunted by a {@creature banshee}. The banshee, Miraal, manifests as a ghostly elf with gills, webbed hands, and webbed feet. It wears spectral garments that sway as though the undead is floating underwater. The banshee can't travel farther than 100 feet from this cave, and thus can't reach the lighthouse.

Miraal was a sea elf killed by Moesko, who took her spellcasting focus—an opalescent conch—as a trophy. The banshee demands that the characters retrieve the conch and bring it to the cave, which will set her spirit to rest. It tries to kill the characters if they refuse, pursuing them as far as it can if they flee.

entries.name: T2. Plateau
entries: Rough-hewn stairs climb the eastern face of the rocky outcropping. The {@creature Harpy||harpies} in area T5 accost the characters as they climb these steps. See {@area area T5|195|x} for details.

At the top of the stairs, a rocky plateau spreads out some 80 feet above the water. Wooden doors leading to area T3 have rusty iron hinges and handles, as well as decorative lightning bolts carved into them. All other doors in the Tower of Storms are of similar construction and ornamentation. None of the doors are locked.

entries.name: T3. Foyer
entries: This 15-foot-high room is empty. Through a dirty window in the south wall, the characters can see two ships' masts jutting crookedly from the water.

entries.name: T4. Shrine of Talos
entries: Describe this location to the players as follows:

The walls of this fifteen-foot-high room are adorned with frescoes that depict ships being tossed on stormy seas, with a dark and terrible god looming above them and smiling. Set into the west wall is a dirty, salt-encrusted window. A stone altar with lightning bolts carved into it stands against the south wall. A metal rod descends from the ceiling above the altar, splitting in two before it embeds itself into the stone.

The smiling figure depicted in the frescoes is the chaotic evil storm god Talos, who can be recognized with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check. Clerics of the Tempest domain succeed on the check automatically.
Through the window, the characters can see the broken masts of several sunken shipwrecks jutting up from the water.

entries.name: Altar
entries: The lightning rod on the roof ({@area area T8|19a|x}) channels electricity into the altar, which converts that raw elemental power into magical energy. The first character to touch the altar gains the Charm of the Storm, described below. Give that character's player the Charm of the Storm card.

entries.name: Charm of the Storm
entries: You become charged with the power of the storm, to the extent that tiny sparks crackle in your eyes. You can cast the {@spell lightning bolt} spell (3rd-level version) as an action. Once used three times, the charm vanishes from you.

Once the altar bestows this benefit, it can't do so again until it recharges. The altar recharges when the lightning rod on the roof (see {@area area T8|19a|x}) is struck by three bolts of lightning from a storm and channels that energy down into the altar. Lightning from other sources doesn't count.

entries.name: T5. Harpies' Aerie
entries: A ledge enclosed by a 3-foot-high stone retaining wall serves as a nest for {@creature Harpy||harpies}. The harpies line their nest with rotting vegetation and the bones of previous meals, which they hunt up and down the coast. The number of harpies present equals the number of characters in the party, including sidekicks (maximum three harpies). A harpy reduced to 10 hit points or fewer tries to fly away on its next turn, hoping to live to fight another day.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who search through the harpies' nest find a {@item potion of water breathing}. If the characters acquire this potion, give them the {@item Potion of Water Breathing} card or they can reference it in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}.

entries.name: T6. Lighthouse Interior
entries: A spiral staircase with an ornate stone railing climbs up the inside wall of this round stone tower. Each staircase landing is 20 feet higher than the one below it.

entries.name: T7. Moesko the Anchorite
entries: This 15-foot-high room has two north-facing windows. A barnacle-encrusted chair stands against the south wall. Sitting in the chair is Moesko, an {@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP} clad in armor made from giant octopus hide. Resting in his lap is an opalescent conch he took from Miraal the sea elf (see {@area area T1|18e|x}).

Beneath his armor, Moesko has a hole in his chest where his heart used to be. If his heart (located in {@area area T9|19c|x}) has been destroyed, Moesko is dead and slumped in the chair. Otherwise, he's alive and demands that intruders leave the Tower of Storms at once or face his wrath. He attacks those who defy him, confident in his ability to defend the lighthouse.
If Moesko is killed but his heart has not yet been destroyed, his body reforms in 24 hours, regaining all its hit points and becoming active again. The new body appears within 5 feet of the heart.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Returning the opalescent conch to {@area area T1|18e|x} dismisses the banshee as its spirit is set free. The characters are then free to sell the conch. Linene Graywind of the {@area Lionshield Coster|02f|x} offers 125 gp for it, or it can be sold for 250 gp in a city such as {@area Neverwinter|015|x}.

entries.name: T8. Rooftop and Lightning Rod
entries: From this vantage point, the characters can see the shattered masts of the five shipwrecks west of the lighthouse ({@area areas T10 to T14|19e|x}). Enclosing the rooftop is a 1-foot-high stone wall with a 2-foot-high iron railing atop it. A similar railing circles the walkway of the lighthouse beacon (area T9), which is 20 feet above this area.

entries.name: Lightning Rod
entries: A 10-foot-tall, wrought-iron lightning rod reaches toward the sky. During a thunderstorm, lightning strikes the rod at random intervals as determined by the DM, and is channeled through the roof to the altar in area T4. A creature that happens to be in contact with the lightning rod when it's struck by a bolt of lightning must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@dice 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: T9. Moesko's Heart
entries: The pinnacle of the lighthouse beacon is partly open to the elements and surrounded by a narrow walkway topped by an iron railing. Three open archways allow the beacon's pulsating green light to spill westward over the sea. This light is so bright that any character who dares look directly at it is {@condition blinded} for 1 minute.

The light originates from Moesko's still-beating heart, which floats in the air 5 feet off the floor. The heart has been magically enlarged to ten times its normal size, and is considered a Small object with AC 10, 10 hit points, and immunity to psychic damage. The heart can't be moved. If reduced to 0 hit points, the heart's light goes out as the organ implodes and is destroyed, leaving no trace behind. Attacks made against the heart have disadvantage unless the attacker is immune to the {@condition blinded} condition or the heart's light is blotted out (by throwing a blanket over it, for example).

entries.name: Exploring the Wrecks
entries: West of the Tower of Storms are five sunken shipwrecks (areas T10 through T14), with only their masts visible. Characters intent on searching the ships for treasure will need {@sense darkvision} or magical light sources to see, as the wrecks are submerged in murky, 20-foot-deep water.

Characters atop the 80-foot-high lighthouse outcropping might try to climb down its slope to reach the water. The slope has abundant handholds but is wet, so that ascending or descending it requires a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A character who fails the check slips and falls, landing in the water below and taking {@dice 1d6} bludgeoning damage per 10 feet fallen.

Three 15-foot-long {@creature Hunter Shark||hunter sharks} glide among the wrecks. Daggermaw is the meanest and hungriest of the three, and it attacks characters without provocation after they finish searching two of the wrecks. If Daggermaw wounds a character, that character's blood in the water attracts the other two sharks, which join the fray on Daggermaw's next turn.

entries.name: T10–T14. Shipwrecks
entries: The crews aboard these five vessels perished when the beacon's evil light compelled them to crash into the rocky outcropping. Fish have picked clean their skeletal remains, which lie scattered throughout the doomed vessels. Three sharks patrol the wreckage (see the "Exploring the Wrecks" sidebar).

The Shipwrecks table below gives the name of each ship and the treasure that can be found within it. A character can spend an action searching the inside of a shipwreck. As part of that action, the character makes a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, finding the ship's treasure on a success. Once a ship's treasure is found, nothing else of value can be retrieved from that wreck.

If the item found is a locked chest, a character can use an action to search the wreck for the key to the chest, finding it with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Conversely, a character can pick the chest's sturdy lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools.

When a magic item is found and identified, give the players the corresponding magic item card or they can reference it in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}. In the case of the {@item +1 weapon} in area T10, choose from among the weapons available ({@item +1 battleaxe}, {@item +1 longbow}, {@item +1 mace}, or {@item +1 shortsword}). Only one {@item +1 weapon} can be found, so choose a weapon with which at least one party member has proficiency.

entries.caption: Shipwrecks
rows: {@item +1 weapon} of your choice, found in the grip of a skeleton that used to be the ship's captain
Starfish clinging to a locked chest filled with straw, within which is packed a delicate, 9-inch-tall, blue quartz statuette of a mermaid (75 gp)
{@item Cloak of many fashions|XGE} worn by the skeleton of the ship's captain
Locked chest containing 120 ep and six pearls (100 gp each) in a black silk pouch

Locked chest that holds a fully charged {@item wand of secrets} and a leather-bound spellbook that contains the wizard spells {@spell blur}, {@spell charm person}, {@spell comprehend languages}, {@spell hold person}, {@spell mage armor}, {@spell sleep}, and {@spell spider climb}

data.name: Umbrage Hill
entries: "Umbrage Hill" is balanced for characters of 3rd level or lower. Higher-level characters won't face great peril here, but they might need to visit this location to buy {@item Potion of Healing||potions of healing} from Adabra Gwynn.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Umbrage Hill got its name after two feuding dwarf clans fought a pitched battle atop it. The cause of their umbrage is a tale lost to time, and only the cairns of the dead now remain. The stone windmill on the hill is a later addition, but is still more than a hundred years old.

Adabra Gwynn, a midwife and apothecary devoted to Chauntea (goddess of agriculture), resides here. A {@creature manticore} driven out of the mountains by Cryovain the white dragon attacks the windmill shortly before the adventurers arrive. Read the following boxed text to set the scene:

Built on the slope of Umbrage Hill is an old stone windmill surrounded by an iron fence. A large winged monster with a spiky tail is trying to knock down the windmill's front door. A woman appears in a second-floor window, waves at you, and yells, "A little help?!"

Adabra uses the {@creature commoner} stat block. Characters can fight or negotiate with the manticore, which ceases its attack and flies away if given at least 25 gp in treasure or a few pounds of meat.
If it's not killed, the manticore could return with its mate to make more trouble in the future.

entries.name: Quest Goals
entries: Adabra declines to return to Phandalin, but the characters can complete the {@area Umbrage Hill Quest|03a|x} by asking her for a note for Harbin Wester confirming her safety. Adabra also gives her saviors one {@item potion of healing} for dealing with the manticore (see below).

entries.name: Umbrage Hill Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of Umbrage Hill.

entries.name: U1. Dwarven Cairns
entries: Dwarves were buried under these rock piles, but their bones, armor, and weapons disintegrated long ago.

entries.name: U2. Ruins of a House
entries: A fireplace is all that remains of this old stone house.

entries.name: U3–U5. Stone Windmill
entries: Adabra uses the millstone on the ground floor (area U3) to grind herbs and other ingredients for poultices and potions. Her quarters are on the second floor (area U4). The third floor (area U5) is a loft where guests can stay.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Adabra sells {@item Potion of Healing||potions of healing} for 50 gp. Give a {@item Potion of Healing} card to any player whose character acquires one of these potions or they can reference it in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}. If you run out of cards, Adabra has no potions left to sell. ({@note There are six cards included with the physical product}).

data.name: Woodland Manse
entries: "Woodland Manse" is balanced for characters of 5th or 6th level, though characters of 3rd or 4th level can survive the challenges of this quest if they rest between encounters.

entries.name: Location Overview
entries: Many years ago, a half-elf wizard interested in the exploration of ancient elven ruins built a stone house in Neverwinter Wood, not far from several ruins that piqued her interest. In the course of her explorations, the wizard disappeared, and the protective magical wards on her home expired. The house fell into disrepair, then eventually into ruin. Ivy has all but engulfed it in the years since.

Recently, a half-orc {@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP} named Grannoc took over the ruined house and planted seeds at the bottom of its well. From these seeds, a malignant tree grew to fill the well and began spawning evil plant monsters called blights (see "{@area Blights|20a|x}" in the {@adventure Creatures|DIP|16} chapter). The blights obey Grannoc, who uses them to defend his woodland manse and kill trespassers within the forest.

entries.name: Quest Goals
entries: To complete the {@area Woodland Manse Quest|03b|x}, the adventurers must eradicate the evil dwelling in and around the manse. Their reward awaits them at {@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6}.

entries.name: Arrival
entries: Characters who come here from {@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6} arrive from the west. Those coming from the {@adventure Circle of Thunder|DIP|3} arrive from the north.

entries.name: Woodland Manse Features
entries: The manse is a dilapidated stone villa enveloped in ivy. Its common features are described below.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Ceilings on the ground floor are 8 feet high and flat. Second-floor ceilings are 15 feet high and peaked, with wooden rafters crossing below them at a height of 10 feet.

entries.name: Doors
entries: Normal doors are made of wood, and are so rotted as to be soft and easily breakable (no ability check required). Secret doors are made of stone and blend in with the surrounding walls. A secret door can be found by a character who searches the surrounding wall and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

entries.name: Ivy
entries: The ivy enveloping the manse is poisonous and makes the walls difficult to climb. Scaling a wall requires a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. A creature that comes into contact with ivy must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or take 2 ({@dice 1d4}) poison damage.

entries.name: Light
entries: Most locations on the ground floor are dark, as the ivy blocks out the natural light except in areas that are open to the sky (such as the courtyard) or that have openings through which sunlight or moonlight can enter. Rooms and halls on the upper level are dimly lit by natural light that filters through holes in the roof.

entries.name: Windows
entries: Windows are 2½-foot wide, 5-foot-high apertures with wooden shutters but no glass. Those along the outside walls are covered with ivy, which must be cleared away before the shutters can be opened or closed.
Describe this location to the players by reading the following boxed text aloud:

Following a trail through the woods, you come to a foggy clearing, in the midst of which stands a crumbling two-story manse all but hidden beneath thorny ivy. The large house is set atop a six-foot-high stone foundation, and the main entrance has a balcony above it. Pumpkins grow wild in patches around the manse, with several wild boars feeding among them. The boars snort with contempt as you draw near.
The trail heading north off the map leads to the {@adventure Circle of Thunder|DIP|3}. The trail heading west leads to {@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6}.

entries.name: Woodland Manse Locations
entries: The following locations are keyed to the map of the woodland manse.

entries.name: W1. Pumpkin Patches
entries: Nine boars graze in the pumpkin patches—one per patch. Of these, six are actual {@creature Boar||boars}. The other three are {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos} in boar form. The anchorites ignore the characters until they try to leave (see "{@area Leaving the Manse|1d9|x}"). If the characters attack a boar, it flees on its turn by darting into the nearby woods. If the characters attack an anchorite, all of the boars and anchorites retaliate. If you need to determine whether a boar is an anchorite or not, roll a {@dice d6}. On a 5 or 6, the boar is an anchorite in disguise.

entries.name: Pumpkins
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a dim aura of transmutation magic around each pumpkin. As an action, a character can carve open a pumpkin to reveal six servings of seeds within. Any creature that eats a serving of pumpkin seeds as an action regains 1 hit point. If a creature eats more than five servings of pumpkin seeds in 1 hour, it must succeed on a DC 12 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for {@dice 1d4} hours.

entries.name: W2. Portico and Balcony
entries: Describe the main entrance of the manse as follows:

Stone steps climb to a portico with a stone balcony overhanging it at a height of ten feet. Vines wrap around the balcony's support pillars and its crumbling stone railing. The ground-floor entrance features a double door with a giant boar's head crudely carved into it. An unmarred double door stands closed on the balcony.

A character can climb up to the balcony with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. If another character assists, the check is made with advantage. Both sets of double doors are free of ivy and safe to open.

entries.name: W3. Downstairs Hall
entries: This undecorated hall features a creaky and moldy wooden staircase.

entries.name: Trapped Stairs
entries: The staircase climbs 10 feet to {@area area W14|1d3|x}. Its upper half has been weakened to the extent that it collapses under 50 pounds or more of weight. A creature on the collapsing stairs must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw to avoid falling onto a bed of wooden spikes planted underneath the staircase. On a failed save, the creature lands on {@dice 1d6} wooden spikes, each one dealing {@dice 1d6} piercing damage.

entries.name: W4. Parlor
entries: The door to this parlor has been smashed to pieces. The room is strewn with broken furniture—the remains of chairs, side tables, and a wine cabinet. A moldy circular rug covers most of the stone floor.

entries.name: W5. Dining Room
entries: The walls are covered with crude drawings in blood that depict boars chasing stick-figure humanoids. A fireplace dominates the south side of the room, and a smashed wooden dining table lies in a heap in the eastern half of the room, surrounded by six broken chairs.

If the characters met the shapechanged {@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP} on the way to the loggers' camp and let it get away (see "{@area A Boar-ing Encounter|14a|x}"), small twig figures rest on the mantelpiece—one representing each party member (including sidekicks). These are {@creature Twig Blight||twig blights} that attack if they are touched or harmed.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Amid the ruined furnishings is a tarnished silver candelabrum worth 25 gp.

entries.name: W6. Kitchen
entries: Nature has run roughshod over this kitchen, whose furnishings are wholly decayed. The outside door was broken down years ago, and rats have chewed holes in the bottom of the door leading to the pantry (area W7).

entries.name: W7. Pantry
entries: Much of the roof above this chamber has collapsed, leaving debris scattered across the floor. Birds have made nests on the wooden shelves that line the north and south walls. Rats long ago devoured anything they could reach, and all other foodstuffs have rotted away.

entries.name: W8. Courtyard
entries: Describe this area to the players as follows:

Stone steps lead down to a flagstoned courtyard that has a pillared arcade to the east. Seven windows on the upper level overlook the courtyard, in the middle of which is a five-foot-wide stone well with thick vines erupting from it.
If the orcs in {@area area W18|1d8|x} have not yet been dealt with, add the following:
Guttural snorts and yells erupt from the southeast corner of the manse, signaling the presence of orcs nearby.
Characters who understand the Orc language can overhear the orcs planning some sort of attack.

entries.name: Gulthias Tree
entries: The well, which is 30 feet deep, contains a Gulthias tree, the roots of which extend deep underground. With little room to spread out, the tree has grown into a malformed column of twisted wood with narrow gaps between its curling branches.

Hidden in the shaft are a number of {@creature Vine Blight||vine blights}—one blight plus one additional blight for each member of the party, not including sidekicks (maximum five blights). The blights form a descending column, with the closest one 5 feet below the well's mouth. With their {@sense blindsight}, they can sense intruders in the courtyard. However, they emerge to attack only when they or the Gulthias tree take damage, or when Grannoc (see {@area area W10|1c6|x}) commands them to do so. Once the blights are out of the shaft, a Medium or smaller character can climb down it, slipping between the branches of the tree with ease (no ability check needed).

The Gulthias tree is a Huge plant with blood for sap. It has AC 15, 250 hit points, vulnerability to fire damage, and no actions, reactions, or defenses. Like an ordinary tree, it's immobile. Unless it's completely uprooted, however, it regrows from its roots even if it's reduced to 0 hit points, regaining 1 hit point every 24 hours.

On any night when the moon is blood red, the Gulthias tree can spawn {@dice 2d6} {@creature Twig Blight||twig blights}, {@dice 1d6} {@creature Needle Blight||needle blights}, or {@dice 1d4} {@creature Vine Blight||vine blights}. These blights split from the tree and crawl out of the well, ready to do Grannoc's bidding.

entries.name: Sounding the Alarm
entries: Any loud noise in the courtyard alerts the creatures in {@area areas W10|1c6|x} and {@area W18|1d8}. Roll initiative for these creatures and the vine blights in the well, and have them react as follows:

items: Grannoc and the twig blights in {@area area W10|1c6|x} investigate immediately. On their first turn, they enter the courtyard, whereupon Grannoc commands the vine blights to emerge from the well. Grannoc and the blights then use their actions to attack their nearest foes.
The orcs in {@area area W18|1d8|x} use their first turn to drop down into area W9. They barge through the door and join the battle on their second turn.

entries.name: W9. Apprentices' Room
entries: Describe this area to the players as follows:

This room was once a bedchamber, kitchen, and dining room rolled into one. Four beds stand along the south wall, with shuttered windows and nightstands between them. Against the west wall are four wardrobes and a cabinet full of plain dishware and cutlery. Four chairs surround a small dining table in the northeast corner, and a trestle table strewn with pots and cooking utensils stands near a blackened fireplace. All the furnishings are made of wood.
The ceiling in the southwest corner of the room has collapsed, filling the area below with debris and leaving a jagged hole through which the room above is visible.

The wizard who built the manse had four apprentices. When it became clear that the wizard wasn't coming back, the apprentices pillaged the library ({@area area W11|1ca|x}) and fled, taking their personal belongings with them.
Any loud noise in this area alerts the orcs in {@area area W18|1d8|x}. On their first turn, they drop down through the hole in the ceiling. On the following turn, they attack.
Adventurers can move tall furniture underneath the hole and climb up it to reach area W18 without having to make an ability check.

entries.name: W10. Wizard's Laboratory
entries: The door on the east side of this room has been smashed down, but any light from the courtyard isn't enough to illuminate the room. Characters with {@sense darkvision} or a light source see the following:

What used to be some sort of laboratory lies in ruins, its furnishings broken and heaped against the walls. In the middle of the room, painted on the floor with mud, is a ten-foot-wide symbol depicting three lightning bolts joined at their tips.

Any character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes the symbol as that of Talos, the evil god of storms. A cleric with the Tempest domain succeeds on the check automatically.
If the characters manage to get this far without alerting Grannoc, they catch him performing a ritual:
Where the lightning bolts converge, a half-orc wearing hide armor performs an eerie dance while consuming the entrails of a dead possum. Standing around the half-orc are several small twig figures.

The half-orc, Grannoc, is an {@creature anchorite of Talos|DIP}. Under his command are a number of {@creature Twig Blight||twig blights}—three blights for each character in the party, not including sidekicks. Characters who watch Grannoc without alerting or interrupting him can determine that he's performing a ritual with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check. Grannoc hopes Talos will answer his prayers and rain destruction down upon Falcon's Hunting Lodge. Any interruption by the characters spoils the ritual and incurs Grannoc's wrath.

entries.name: Map
entries: Grannoc has a map scrawled on the torn-off flap of a leather satchel. It shows Neverwinter Wood and marks the location of the {@adventure Circle of Thunder|DIP|3}.

entries.name: W11. Library
entries: This area extends through both floors of the house. Describe it to the players as follows:

This room has a ten-foot-high wooden balcony forming its upper level, reached by a wooden spiral staircase curling down to the flagstone floor. Tall, empty bookcases line the walls, their shelves mostly bowed and broken. On the lower level, east of two pillars, are four old desks with chairs tucked behind them. A few moldy books are scattered about.

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: One of the bookcases on the balcony conceals a secret door into area W12. Tugging on the bookcase causes it and the secret door to swing open.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The books found here are old texts written in Elvish that describe long-lost elven kingdoms and civilizations. They are too damaged to be worth anything. Additionally, one desk has a small book tucked under one of its back legs to level it off. The book is titled {@i Elvish Idioms}, and its pages have been cut out to conceal a tiny leather packet containing {@item dust of disappearance}. If the characters find the packet and identify the dust, give the players the {@item Dust of Disappearance} card or they can reference it in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}.

entries.name: W12. Master Bedroom
entries: A four-poster bed stands between two shuttered windows against the west wall. Other furnishings include a desk and chair against the north wall and an empty wardrobe against the east wall. A fireplace built into the south wall features an elegantly carved mantelpiece.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of conjuration magic emanating from the fireplace mantel. Any character who searches it and succeeds on a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check discovers that the mantelpiece is actually a lid concealing a long, hidden compartment. The wizard who built the manse hid her {@item staff of birdcalls|XGE} here. If the characters obtain and identify the staff, give the players the {@item Staff of Birdcalls|XGE} card or they can reference it in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}.

entries.name: W13. Magic Item Vault
entries: This room has been sealed for years behind its secret door. When the characters open the secret door, describe the room's features as follows:
Hanging on a hook on the far wall is a handsome cloak that billows softly as the door opens. Against the north wall sits a wooden chest with tiny clawed feet.

The chest weighs 30 pounds and is magically locked. A {@spell knock} spell unlocks it, or the chest can be smashed open. It's a Small object with AC 15, 20 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The garment hanging on the hook is a {@item cloak of billowing|XGE}, and the chest contains an {@item immovable rod} wrapped in a black cloth. If the characters acquire and identify these magic items, give the players the {@item Cloak of Billowing|XGE} and {@item Immovable Rod} cards  or they can reference them in the {@5etools Magic Items Listing|items.html}.

entries.name: W14. Upstairs Hall
entries: Describe this area to the players as follows:

The walls of this L-shaped hall are lined with closed doors and shuttered windows. Between them are hooks where decorations once hung. A fireplace along one wall has a large insectoid head mounted above it. Natural light enters through a hole in the roof at the east end of the hall. The floor beneath the collapsed roof is strewn with debris.
The wooden staircase that leads downstairs is trapped (see {@area area W3|1b8|x}).
The head mounted above the fireplace is that of an {@creature ankheg} (see "{@area Ankheg|208|x}" in the {@adventure Creatures|DIP|16} chapter for an illustration).

The hallway leading to {@area area W12|1ce|x} is dark. {@creature Stirge||Stirges} hang from the rafters here—three stirges per party member, not including sidekicks (maximum twelve stirges). The hungry stirges attack any warm-blooded creature that enters the area.

entries.name: W15. Bathroom
entries: This room has a conical roof and an open window to the north, through which ivy grows. A cast-iron tub with clawed feet stands in the middle of the room. Next to the tub is a rusty iron water pump that still works, drawing water from a hot spring under the house.

entries.name: W16. Slanted Rooftop
entries: Sections of this wood-shingled roof have collapsed into {@area area W7|1be|x}, leaving gaping holes. The westernmost 15-foot-square section of roof collapses if 50 pounds or more of weight is placed on it. Any creature standing on this section of the roof when it collapses must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall into area W7 below, taking 3 ({@dice 1d6}) bludgeoning damage on impact.

entries.name: W17. Upper Arcade
entries: This corridor is enclosed by two double doors and four open windows. Characters can easily sidestep the ivy growing in through the windows to the east. If the orcs in area W18 haven't been dispatched yet, the characters hear their raucous talk through the southern double door.

entries.name: W18. Guest Room
entries: This room has been claimed by hostile {@creature Orc||orcs} in league with Grannoc. Four orcs are here, plus an additional orc for each character in the party, not including sidekicks. The orcs are sharpening their weapons in anticipation of an attack on {@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6}. The orcs have destroyed this room's once-fine furnishings, leaving nothing of value. A hole in the southwest corner of the floor leads to {@area area W9|1c4|x} below.

entries.name: Leaving the Manse
entries: When the characters finish exploring the manse, they are attacked as they make their exit. The attacking force consists of any {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos} and {@creature Boar||boars} in {@area area W1|1b4|x} that were not previously killed or forced to flee. In addition, {@creature Needle Blight||needle blights} emerge from the woods to join the battle—two blights for each character in the party, not including sidekicks.

entries.name: Counterattack!
entries: The day after the characters attack the manse, dark clouds settle over Neverwinter Wood as the {@creature Anchorite of Talos|DIP|anchorites of Talos} stage a counterattack against {@adventure Falcon's Hunting Lodge|DIP|6}. {@creature Gorthok the Thunder Boar|DIP} smashes through the lodge's palisade, allowing twenty {@creature Orc||orcs} to storm the lodge.
If the characters aren't present when the lodge is attacked, Falcon and his servants flee on Falcon's riding horse and make their way to Phandalin, surrendering the lodge to the orcs.

data.name: Ending the Adventure
entries: The adventure can end in one of several ways. Ideally, it concludes with the defeat of Cryovain the white dragon, the completion of all the Phandalin quests, or both. By then, the characters should be 6th level. Give the players a chance to wrap up loose ends before declaring the adventure over. For example, the characters might need to return to {@area Phandalin|02a|x} to collect an outstanding reward or notify townsfolk that the dragon has been dealt with. Armed with such good news, Townmaster {@area Harbin Wester|037|x} might plan a feast in the heroes' honor. What happens next is up to you.

If the worst happens and the characters die, their adventure is also over. You can let the players roll up new characters and pick up where their last ones left off, or you can also start over with new characters, tweaking quests as you see fit to surprise players who might be familiar with them.

You might also expand the adventure by inventing new quests and new locations. Another introductory product called the {@i D&D Starter Set} contains an adventure titled {@adventure Lost Mine of Phandelver|LMoP}, which takes place in the same region as this adventure and is designed for characters of 1st through 5th level. You can add locations from that adventure to this one, giving your players and their characters even more places to explore.

Once you've exhausted all the content this adventure has to offer, you can run it again for different players, or you can find an adventure that takes the characters beyond 6th level. The "Where Next?" section below offers a few suggestions.

entries.name: Where Next?
entries: If your players want to advance their characters beyond 6th level, they'll need the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB} to do so.

If you plan to run more D&D for your players, you'll also need the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}, the {@book Monster Manual|MM}, and new adventures. Many DMs like to create their own adventures. Others prefer to run published adventures like this one. You'll find fun, inexpensive adventures for characters of all levels and groups of all sizes in the DMs Guild ({@link www.dmsguild.com|http://www.dmsguild.com}). Wizards of the Coast also publishes hardcover books that contain stand-alone adventures that can entertain you and your players for months. You can run these adventures as written, or you can do what many experienced DMs do: use the parts you like, ignore the rest, and add a few surprises of your own. Here are brief descriptions of some of these published adventures, to help you choose the one that's right for you.

{@adventure Curse of Strahd|CoS} {@b (for levels 1–10)}. Eerie mist engulfs the adventurers and transports them to Barovia, a land of Gothic horror ruled by the vampire Strahd von Zarovich. To escape Barovia, the characters must confront and defeat the vampire in his terrifying castle.

{@adventure Hoard of the Dragon Queen|HotDQ} {@b (for levels 1–7)} and {@adventure The Rise of Tiamat|RoT} {@b (for levels 8–15)}. Tiamat, the Queen of Evil Dragons, is trapped in the Nine Hells—but not for long if her servants amass enough treasure to buy her freedom. This adventure is split across two books.

{@adventure Out of the Abyss|OotA}{@b  (for levels 1–15)}. Trapped in a vast subterranean labyrinth called the Underdark, the characters must fight monsters and forge alliances to survive. Along the way, they encounter wandering demons that are spreading madness wherever they go.

{@adventure Princes of the Apocalypse|PotA}{@b  (for levels 1–15)}. East of Phandalin lies the peaceful Dessarin Valley, where four evil elemental cults have gained a foothold. To protect the valley and its settlements, the characters must root out and destroy these cults and their leaders.

{@adventure Storm King's Thunder|SKT}{@b  (for levels 1–10)}. Evil giants seek to conquer the Sword Coast. If the characters can find Hekaton the storm giant king, he can put an end to the giants' rampage, but a secret enemy stands in their way.

{@adventure Tomb of Annihilation|ToA}{@b  (for levels 1–11)}. A trap-ridden tomb holds a device that is capturing and devouring the souls of the dead. To save these poor souls, the characters must cross a vast jungle, descend into the tomb, and defeat the horrors within.

{@adventure Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage|WDMM}{@b  (for levels 5–20)}. Beneath the city of Waterdeep lies the dungeon of Undermountain, ruled by the mad wizard Halaster Blackcloak. Many heroes enter, but few escape!
